sender.senderstreetaddress: Novartis Pharmaceuticals Corp. Bldg 419, One Health Plaza

reaction.primarysourcereaction: Overdose (applying one 13.5mg patch and six 18mg patches)
One 13.5mg patch and six 18mg patches were applied/falling to remove the 13.5mg patch

drug.drugdosagetext: 99 mg, (one 13.5 mg patch and six 18 mg patches)

summary.narrativeincludeclinical:
Case number PHHY2012JP105146, is a combined initial spontaneous reports received from a physician on 13 Nov 2012, again from the physician on 13 Nov 2012, from the prescribing physician on 14 Nov 2012 and from another hospital physician on 15 Nov 2012 with follow up report received from the physician on 28 Nov 2012 and follow-up report received from the prescribing physician on 05 Dec 2012. This case refers to an 85-year-old female patient. The patient's concurrent conditions included hypertension and interstitial pneumonia. Concomitant medication included amlodipine at the dose of 2.5 mg at unknown frequency. The patient lived alone. The patient's score on the Hasegawa scale was 11, indicating moderate or worse dementia. The patient was initially treated with Aricept (donepezil hydrochloride). The patient received Exelon transdermal patches (rivastigmine) for dementia Alzheimer’s type from 17 Aug 2012 at a dose of 4.5mg daily. The patient generally applied Exelon patches herself, normally when using an adult daycare service. When the patient made a monthly visit to a physician, the physician applied the Exelon patch. On 14 Sep 2012, the dose of Exelon was increased to 9mg daily. On 12 Oct 2012, the dose of Exelon was increased to 13.5mg daily. On 09 Nov 2012, the dose of Exelon was increased to 18mg daily. On 11 Nov 2012, the patient applied a 13.5mg Exelon patch and an 18mg Exelon patch at the same time. Between 11 Nov 2012 and 13 Nov 2012, the patient used an overdose of Exelon, failing to remove the 13.5 mg patch applied on 10 Nov 2012 and applying 6 to 7 new Exelon 18 mg patches. Thus, one 13.5 mg patch and six 18 mg patches were applied, a total dose of 99 mg daily. The patient reported that she had applied Exelon patches to both shoulders. On 13 Nov 2012, due to the overdose, the patient experienced abdominal pain, tremor (myoclonus-like movement of thumbs), decreased consciousness, somnolence, miosis, dehydration and incontinence due to which she was hospitalized. It was reported that when the patient had lost consciousness. However, while the patient was being transported to the hospital, her eyes were closed but she was able to respond slightly when spoken to. On an unspecified date, the patient was examined at the clinic where Exelon was prescribed and then admitted to the hospital where the other reporting physician worked. At the hospital, all of the patches were removed, and the patient's course was observed. Bradycardia and arrhythmia was absent. The patient's vital signs were stable. On 13 Nov 2012, treatment with Exelon patch was discontinued. On an unspecified date, it was thought that the cholinesterase level had decreased due to the overdose, and had then come back up again. Later, the patient’s pupils became slightly larger, 1.5mm, and blood cholinesterase started to increase. On an unspecified date, the patient's pupils returned to their normal size. The patient's pupils did not dilate to a larger size than normal. No symptoms such as gastrointestinal symptoms, headaches or dizziness were observed. The patient was in a good condition. The patient had not been discharged, but discharge was planned for the near future. The outcome of event overdose, incontinence, consciousness decreased, somnolence and dehydration was condition improving. The outcome of a myoclonus-like jerking movement of the thumbs tremor and miosis were reported as complete recovery on an unspecified date. The outcome of abdominal pain and blood cholinesterase level abnormal, one 13.5mg patch and six 18mg patches were applied and failing to remove the 13.5mg patch were not reported. Overdose, abdominal pain, tremor, consciousness decreased, somnolence, miosis, dehydration and incontinence were considered serious (hospitalization) by both physicians. Seriousness and causality of the event blood cholinesterase level abnormal, one 13.5mg patch and six 18mg patches were applied and failing to remove the 13.5mg patch were not reported. Both physicians reported that overdose, abdominal pain, tremor (myoclonus-like movement of thumbs), consciousness decreased, somnolence, miosis, dehydration and incontinence were related to Exelon therapy. The prescribing physician commented that the patient had apparently been applying one patch every day; the physician did not know reason why the patient had applied seven patches at once. The hospital physician commented that the patient had probably thought that the Exelon patch was something like a poultice. The hospital physician commented that it was problematic that a non-specialist private clinic was easily able to prescribe Exelon to a patient living alone.
Follow up report received from the physician on 28 Nov 2012: Updated event verbatim Tremor (myoclonus-like jerking movement of thumbs), outcome of event miosis and tremor and narration.
Follow-up received from the prescribing physician on 05 Dec 2012: Updated patient's demographic, event onset date, event outcome and event description.
summary.sendercomment: MAC: Based on reported data, a causal relationship with the suspected drug cannot be rule out.
